title: Avengers director hits back at Martin Scorsese’s criticism of Marvel
text:
Now Joss has spoken out (Picture: Rex Features)

The director of the OG Avengers film, Joss Whedon, has hit back at Martin Scorsese’s critique of Marvel films.

After legendary director Martin compared Marvel’s award-winning flicks to a theme park, as is his right, the directors involved in the Marvel Cinematic Universe have defended the films.

Now Avengers director Joss has leapt into action, after Guardians Of The Galaxy director James Gunn also spoke his opinion on the matter, after the Wolf Of Wall Street filmmaker recently claimed that Marvel films are ‘not cinema’.

The 55-year-old director – who helmed The Avengers in 2012 – initially tweeted Scorsese’s statement, typing: ‘It isn’t the cinema of human beings trying to convey emotional, psychological experiences to another human being.’

Then, he discussed Martin’s claims in reference to filmmaker James and the Guardians of the Galaxy franchise.

He continued: ‘I first think of @JamesGunn, how his heart & guts are packed into GOTG. I revere Marty, & I do see his point, but…

‘Well there’s a reason why “I’m always angry”. (sic)

It comes after Martin previously admitted he’d tried and failed to enjoy the Marvel movies, which include money-spinning franchises like Infinity War and Endgame, Guardians of the Galaxy and Captain America.

Martin has his views (Picture: Invision)

According to the director, the genre simply didn’t chime with his own cinematic tastes.

Which is fine, sure, but he’s enraged a whole franchise of fans in the process…

He shared: ‘I don’t see them. I tried, you know? But that’s not cinema.

‘Honestly, the closest I can think of them, as well made as they are, with actors doing the best they can under the circumstances, is theme parks.

James Gunn is a beloved Marvel director (Picture: WireImage)

‘It isn’t the cinema of human beings trying to convey emotional, psychological experiences to another human being.’

Over the weekend James spoke out on social media about Martin’s comments.

‘Martin Scorsese is one of my 5 favorite living filmmakers. I was outraged when people picketed The Last Temptation of Christ without having seen the film. I’m saddened that he’s now judging my films in the same way,’ James wrote.

Advertisement

Advertisement

He went on to add: ‘That said, I will always love Scorsese, be grateful for his contribution to cinema, and can’t wait to see The Irishman.’

James’ comments saw mixed reactions from fans – while some agreed with him and argued that Martin’s claims were unwarranted, others argued that the two situations can’t be compared.

The 53-year-old went on to write: ‘For those tweeting me I’m somehow saying zealots picketing Last Temptation is the same as Scorsese judging my films, I’m not. What outraged me about the picketers at the time of Last Temptation is NOT that they thought the film was blasphemous. Nor that they were picketing.

‘Doing those thing are within their rights. What bothered me was that 99% of them were doing it without having seen the movie.’

Can we just all agree all their films are amazing.
